ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to put together and give presentations (65-70 minutes). From my and others presentations, I learned about the mathematics behind modern public key cryptography/how number theory is used in the area. We covered a substantial chunk of An Introduction to Mathematical Cryptography (second edition) by Hoffstein, Pipher, and Silverman.
Giving academic talks, introduction to cryptology
The biggest skill I gained from this course was in teaching - each student was required to teach two class periods of material over zoom. I also learned about some common cryptosystems.
I feel much more comfortable presenting to my classmates and have realized how much research aids my ability to absorb information.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course was great as is. We delved deep into mathematical cryptography, which was super interesting, and all of us got a chance to work on our presentation skills. Also, the professor would provide some brief insights at the end of every student lecture, which was helpful.

I felt somewhat less engaged with this course than with my other courses. Maybe a few problem sets or some written project would make it more engaging? I kind of liked having a course with lower workload, but I do want to be honest and say that I was less engaged as a result.

It was a good opportunity to gain experience teaching content to peers. Sometimes I felt like there wasn't enough content per lecture to keep things interesting, and a good chunk of the time each lecture ended up being spent on example problems which I sometimes found repetitive.

The lectures are quite long to be run by students, however I think the point is to challenge us in that arena. I think it would be great if it was required at the end of every lecture (last 10 minutes maybe) that the other students try to solve some problems with the presenter.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course ran smoothly. Students simply gave 60-75 minute lectures each class, and to facilitate these lectures, we used Powerpoints or Beamer presentations.

I've never seen what math seminar is like in person, but I did not feel that the course was affected too much by remote learning. I think talks work quite well over zoom.Other than that, I did not have too much interaction with him because of the limite
This course was adapted well to virtual format (zoom).
All went well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Of course! If youre considering taking the senior seminar, chances are that you need it in order to graduate. You might as well register for the section whose subject matter you find more compelling. I found the subject matter for this section of the senior seminar, mathematical cryptography, to be super interesting.

I wouldn't really recommend it if you want to learn cryptology in general because there aren't problem sets or exams to really make you study the material in-depth. If you want to learn academic public speaking, maybe it is a good course for you, but then again, you only give 1-2 talks. So, in general, I would say that this course is probably not worth taking unless you are a math major and want to fulfill the senior requirement.

You should take this course if and only if you are a senior math major who would like to not do a thesis. If I were simply hoping to learn about the topic (cryptography), I think an independent study would have been a more efficient way to do this.
Although in the moment I was frustrated with the class, I really grew to love it because it opened up another tool for me to use when I am struggling to solve a problem.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Students gave live virtual lectures over Zoom.
This course was purely remote with live lectures given by students.
NA
Meetings with professor to discuss lectures. Lectures driven by students.
Students gave the lectures
